For example, Y might take the value 1 if an infant dies in the first year of life and 0 if she or he survives the first year. The probability of infant death can be written concisely: Pr(Y=1). The definition of the 'odds of death' is odds(Y=1) = Pr(Y=1)/Pr(Y=0. In words, the odds of death is the probability of death divided by the probability of survival. So when we say the odds of death for a newborn child in rural Nepal is 99 to 1000 or 99/1000 = 0.099, we mean that there are 99 chances an infant will die and 1000 chances it will live. How many chances are there in total? (99+1000). What is the probability of death? The number of chances of death divided by the total number of chances or 99/(99+1000) which we can write (99/1000)/{ 99/1000 + 1000/1000}. We can see that, given an odds of an event, the probability of that event is Pr(Y=1) = odds(Y=1)/{1+odds(Y=1)). For those who prefer a direct algebraic approach, by the definition of odds: odds(Y=1) = Pr(Y=1)/Pr(Y=0) = Pr(Y=1)/{1-Pr(Y=1)} so that multiplying through by {1-Pr(Y=1)} gives Pr(Y=1) = odds (Y=1)*{1-Pr(Y=1)} = odds (Y=1) - Pr(Y=1)*odds(Y=1) .
